fields.title_content: A Short Guide on Where to Live in College
fields.body_content:
According to a 2020 survey conducted by Cigna, a health service company, young adults between 18- and 22-years-old are the loneliest people among all age groups in America today. It’s a startling fact, since college students are surrounded by many people on their campus and still have ties back home. Yet many college students will experience loneliness.

 

One of my international friends from Taiwan said it best: “As an international student, I think loneliness is ... inevitable ... while studying abroad. ... I believe that it is always hard while we are trying to blend into another culture, but we can always choose to appreciate [differences] between people.”

 According to a 2020 survey conducted by Cigna, a health service company, young adults between 18- and 22-years-old are the loneliest people among all age groups in America today. It’s a startling fact, since college students are surrounded by many people on their campus and still have ties back home. Yet many college students will experience loneliness.

One of my international friends from Taiwan said it best: “As an international student, I think loneliness is ... inevitable ... while studying abroad. ... I believe that it is always hard while we are trying to blend into another culture, but we can always choose to appreciate [differences] between people.”

 

 

Photo by Sofia Garza from Pexels

 

When I arrived at my college a few years back, I felt excited to discover my meaning and purpose. I wanted to have an extraordinary college experience, happily pursuing my college degree. Halfway through my freshman year, things took a turn. 

 

I made connections and added people on social media, but I didn’t have a true friend who knew me well. I didn’t feel like I was connecting with others. On a lonely night, I attended an outdoor concert with my roommates, even though I didn’t care for the music my roommates enjoyed. In that moment, I felt lonely.

 

I experienced loneliness as a domestic student. Perhaps you’ve also experienced loneliness back in your home country as well. International students are more likely to experience loneliness and isolation when they move to their new home in a foreign country.  Adjusting to a new culture and language is obviously challenging. But even ordinary activities, such as grocery shopping and going to the doctor, become strangely complex and remind international students that living abroad is not easy. On top of that, international students must make new friends and face the pressures of performing well in school, so it’s easy to feel overwhelmed. 

 

What can we do about this problem of loneliness? Here are three things I tried that helped me greatly with the problem of loneliness, and I hope you can find these suggestions helpful.

 

 

Photo by Belle Co from Pexels

 

Join a Campus Group 

 

There are so many options such as mentorship clubs, English-speaking programs, study sessions, events, hobbies and more that your International Student Center can help you find. To meet other people who share your interests, you can explore your college’s interest groups. You can start building relationships before you arrive in the US. You can even make a social media group of students from your home country as a way to get to know each other better. If you’ve already made some friendships, your college experience will be even better once you’ve arrived. You can check out our ISMP social media websites and our WeChat to make connections with our mentors and other mentees.

 

I joined a college campus group during my freshman year. I met people who shared the same interests, such as cooking together and playing sports. Those people eventually became my friends who helped me throughout the ups and downs of college. 

 

Ask for Help 

 

International students often have to work twice as hard as domestic students to understand English and express their thoughts. You might feel like you have to work hard and that others expect you to do well. If you’re under a lot of pressure, it’s crucial to ask for help when you need it. It’s helpful to open up to others about your difficulties, rather than keeping everything locked up inside. 

 

Your campus has tutoring centers, writing centers, career centers and more resources to help you succeed. Professors and teaching assistants hold office hours to give students advice and to help them to do better. If you share with others about your situation, they can see how you are trying to do your best and get you the help you need. 

 

Be Open-minded

 

College is one of the best times of your life. You have the opportunity to learn everyday about a new culture and make life-long friends with domestic students as well as other international students from all over the world. A study from St. Cloud State University shows that people who are willing to communicate with people from different cultures have more friends from foreign countries than those who are less willing to reach out. 

 

But intercultural communication can be confusing and challenging. What’s important is being open-minded and understanding about different cultural customs. 

 

If you want to talk to a domestic student, you can introduce yourself and try to learn about their culture. You can say, “This is new to me. What is the right thing to do in this situation?” Most people are happy to share with you about their culture. Don’t feel like you need to blend in; rather, try learning something new about domestic students’ culture, and also share your unique experiences and stories about your culture. 

Don’t worry - you’re not the only one feeling lonely or needing help! Our program offers opportunities to meet new people and to make friends. We also offer webinars on how to get to know your roommates and how to survive your first month of school. Check out our mentorship program for more info, and sign up today! 

References: 

 

  1. https://www.cigna.com/static/www-cigna-com/docs/about-us/newsroom/studies-and-reports/combatting-loneliness/cigna-2020-loneliness-report.pdf

  2. Jeffrey W. Kassing (1997) Development of the intercultural willingness to communicate scale, Communication Research Reports, 14:4, 399-407, DOI: 10.1080/08824099709388683

Header photo credit: Photo by Sofia Garza from Pexels
fields.preview_text: Coming to America soon and donâ€™t know where to stay? There are so many different options to choose from! Wondering which one is right for you? Take a look at this short guide to see your choices.

fields.title_content: 5 Tips You Must Know to Succeed in Your Online Classes
fields.body_content:
Although virtual learning isn’t for everyone, due to the coronavirus situation, many schools are moving all of their classes online. From my own experience of working in a virtual world during the COVID-19 pandemic, I’ve compiled some helpful tips that can help you as you take online classes.

 

Tip #1: Get dressed.

Photo credit: Burgess Milner on unsplash.com

 

Rather than rolling out of bed and spending the entire day in your pajamas or sweats, wash up and get dressed as if you were actually going to an in-person class. You will feel more awake and alert as you attend your online class. 

 

Tip #2: Create a productive learning space. 

Photo credit: Aleksi Tappura on unsplash.com 

 

Create a place to study where you won’t be distracted. Don’t sit on the couch or your bed because you’ll naturally want to fall asleep. (Each time I work on the couch, I just want to take a nap.) It’s good to sit at a table or desk where you can concentrate and be in working mode. I generally like to be in a space where it’s clean, quiet, and clutter-free so that I can best concentrate on my work. 

 

Tip #3: Minimize distractions

 

Photo credit: Jonas Leupe on unsplash.com

 

Minimize distractions by turning off notifications on your computer. You’ll avoid constantly seeing texts or messages that can draw your attention away as you try to focus on your online class. And I know it’s hard, but close other tabs on your browser so that you’re not checking Facebook, Instagram, or the news as your professor is trying to teach the lecture. It’s also a good idea to put your phone on silent so that you’re not constantly hearing your ringtone or buzzing sounds from your phone. I personally like to put my phone away or place it face down so that I don’t see the screen light up with each notification that comes in. 

 

Tip #4: Take breaks

 

Photo credit: Arek Adeoye on unsplash.com

 

It’s tiring watching lecture after lecture or always doing your homework. Generally, for every one hour of work you put in, it’s good to give yourself a 10-minute break. You can take a break by going outside, going on a walk, stretching, grabbing a snack, reading a book or article. This will help refresh your mind. As humans, we’re not wired to work for long periods of time without breaks. We need to give our minds and brains a break from focusing on one thing. This will help you to think more clearly and look at the problem you’ve been trying to solve or the paper you’re trying to write from a new perspective.  

 

Tip #5: Set a schedule

 

Stick to a regular weekly schedule by setting aside the hours where you’ll attend class and study. It’s also good to set a time for when you’ll take your breaks. You should also limit how long your break will be so that you don’t end up spending five hours playing video games or watching Korean dramas ðŸ˜±. 

 

Some ways to keep track of your time is to set a timer on your phone or computer that alerts you when time is up. You can also create your weekly schedule using Google Calendar to plan out each hour of your days. If you don’t like using online scheduling apps like Google Calendar, writing out your schedule the good old fashion way using pen and paper in a planner is also a good idea. I personally like to write my schedule on a mini whiteboard for my desk. 

 

It’s also a good idea to schedule important dates in your calendar. This includes midterms, finals, due dates of papers, and any vacation or travel plans you have coming up. This will help you remember what’s to come. I’ve had some friends forget that they had a midterm on the day of the test, and so they weren’t prepared to take it. I’ve also had friends who just didn’t show up to their test because they forgot about it. Scheduling things in is key. 

 

Need more help focusing on your classes? Sign up for our mentorship program today to get personalized tips on time management and productivity!

 

Header and thumbnail photo credit: Scott Graham on Unsplash.com
fields.preview_text: Although virtual learning isnâ€™t for everyone, due to the coronavirus situation, many schools are moving all of their classes online. Here are some helpful tips that can help you as you take online classes.

fields.preview_text: Nobody wants to be lonely. Here are three things you can do as an international student to manage feelings of loneliness. Photo by Retha Ferguson from Pexels.
